Package algorithms.graphs

Class Modularity

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.graphs.Modularity
  • public class Modularity
extends java.lang.Object
    Newman 2006, "Modularity and community structure in networks" https://arxiv.org/pdf/physics/0602124.pdf modularity is a graph quality function over possible divisions of a network. ... The modularity is, up to a multiplicative constant, the number of edges falling within groups minus the expected number in an equivalent network with edges placed at random. (A precise mathematical formulation is given below.) The modularity can be either positive or negative, with positive values indicating the possible presence of community structure. Thus, one can search for community structure precisely by looking for the divisions of a network that have positive, and preferably large, values of the modularity. on a spectral approximation: maximizing the term involving the leading eigenvalue and completely ignoring all the others turns out to be effective here... ignoring the inconvenient fact that it is not possible to make s perfectly parallel to u1 and go ahead and maximize the term in Î²1 anyway. Given that we are free to choose the sizes of our two groups of vertices, the greatest value of the coefficient NOTE: a paper with tables summarizing different modularity algorithms for different definitions of communities as disjoint or sharing members is Table 2 on page 5 of https://arxiv.org/pdf/1708.00977.pdf 
     Newman 2006:
    defines modularity using eignevectors of a characteritic matrix

Moore, Finding community structure in very large networks. Phys. Rev. E 70, 066111 (2004). NOTE: Newman generates random graphs for testing too: https://arxiv.org/pdf/cond-mat/0209450.pdf https://arxiv.org/pdf/cond-mat/0210146.pdf

    • Method Detail

      • girvanNewman2002

        public double girvanNewman2002​(Dendogram.DendogramLayer layer,
                               SimpleLinkedListNode[] originalAdjacencyList,
                               double nEdges)
        given the original graph adjacency list, compute the modularity of the graph using the connected components from an iteration of the girvan-newman algorithm for edge betweenness scores. Reference: Newman and Girvan 2004, PHYSICAL REVIEW E 69, 026113, "Finding and evaluating community structure in networks" NOTE: If the number of within-community edges is no better than random, we will get Q = 0. value approaching the maximum, Q = 1, indicate strong community structure [50]. values tend to be 0.3 to 0.7 and higher values are rare. NOTE: communities are disjoint sets for Girvan-Newman 2002 and 2004
        Parameters:
        originalAdjacencyList -
        layer - the results of an iteration of the girvan-newman algorithm followed by use of DisjointForest.connectedComponents to find the disjoint sets of connected nodes.
        nEdges - the number of edges in the original graph. presumably the code using this method has calculated it once for the original graph already, to pass in to this method over repeated uses.
        Returns:
        the modularity as defined by girvan & newman 2002 and Newman & Girvan 2004.
